title: Avatar: Fire and Ash
reviewText: wow the most tense sequence i ever saw in my life. cool archery action, big ocean set pieces, a horse filled with men‚Ä¶so excited for the odyssey i basically paid 25 dollars to watch the special imax odyssey preview and the avengers teaser and the 3d grogu trailer, and expected avatar 3 to be super meh and maybe a good xmas napportunity. but color me mildly surprised; fire and ash is definitely the best one so far. the world is super beautiful and i love all the animal designs. the movie is engineered to be 3d in the best way and the high frame rate is done really well. it might make it look more like a video game but at least everything isn‚Äôt a blurry mess. i feel a little bit more connected to all of the characters. the thing that takes me out of the movie the most is the same as the second film: sigourney weaver playing a child does not work and it is super weird and it‚Äôs even weirder now that her character is in love with a child. stop it! i really hope this series starts to ask more thought-provoking questions because five movies about jake soooolly protecting his family from sky people is starting to get very tiring. this movie kind of starts to get interesting when neytiri and jake argue about her hatred of humans and stuff but it doesn‚Äôt seem to go anywhere. and stop with the fake deaths. how many times am i gonna see colonel quanch or whatever his name is get killed. and then in the next movie he cracks a joke about how he doesn‚Äôt die to easily. this is definitely a movie directed by a boy. if you like movies directed by boys you will certainly enjoy this one.

title: The Long Walk
reviewText: i saw a critic say it‚Äôs the best stephen king adaptation of all time and i was like ‚Äúreally? better than the shining?‚Äù and yeah maybe THE LONG WALK is better‚Ä¶ this movie is so efficient. you‚Äôre never given any more than what‚Äôs necessary. everything feels so intentional. it‚Äôs 50 boys walking. and walking. these actors i‚Äôve never heard of are so good. ‚Äúwe‚Äôre almost at the end. say something real.‚Äù¬†why am i crying? the violence is so brutal and effective on me the viewer and also the characters. it never shies away from he (literal) shit that they have to endure. i was stunned by the quiet beauty of the landscape with this one desolate asphalt strip slicing through. i know its an adapted story but these characters are so good. credit to the screenwriter(s). it‚Äôs half cringe half funny in the beginning in a stephen king way but also in a stephen king way all innocence is quickly and brutally stripped from these young men‚Äôs souls. the ending is not necessarily what i wanted as a viewer who grew to care for these characters but the impact is felt. felt DEEPLY. the stephen king vibe is totally there. very well done. my favorite film of the year.

title: Yi Yi
reviewText: This movie doesn't feel inadequate; it makes ME feel inadequate. I feel as though I simply don't have enough life experience to fully absorb the breadth of Yang's reflections on life. It's like I can only scrape off a bit of the surface. There's a difference in knowing what's happening versus actually feeling the depth of emotion that each character experiences. I can tell that when I rewatch this in 50 years it's going to smash my heart to bits, but right now I'm only 22 and there's no way I can appreciate it fully in the way that other people do.

title: Wonka
reviewText:
On the eve of my final breath, I found myself ensnared in the tendrils of an uncharted science, where memories became as malleable as taffy, and time whispered its elusive tales. The dimly lit chamber cradled the specters of beloved kin, their gazes serving as portals to an impending adieu.

Clad in antiseptic whites, the scientists unveiled an elixir‚Äîthe Chronochoc‚Äîa seductive promise to iron out life's wrinkles, to unwind the spool of existence. "December 15, 2023. Transport me to the day Wonka's enchantment first unfolded before my unsuspecting eyes," I declared, the syrupy essence of nostalgia lingering on my lips.

My daughter, tears cascading like molten chocolate, clutched a relic from our familial trove. "Dad, you cannot obliterate the imprints of time. What of us? The memories that sculpted our shared narrative."

My son, his voice quivering like a delicate praline, echoed her sentiments. "Ponder the milestones, the anecdotes resonating through the labyrinth of time."

Yet, the beguiling melody of Wonka's chocolate realm beckoned‚Äîa confectionary sonnet weaving through the epochs. "I must return, unearth the symphony of innocence," I insisted, my heart heavy with the burdens of my cocoa-infused resolution.

My wife, guardian of memories and connoisseur of patience, clung to a weathered photograph, whispering, "What if you forfeit us, relinquish the shared murmurs of our love?"

In her gaze, a tempest of sentiments reflected‚Äîa turbulent sea of emotions. "I shall not forget. But in the twilight of my days, I must pursue the echoes of a realm where candy canes stood tall, and oompa loompas danced."

As the needle, herald of temporal metamorphosis, approached, the room morphed into an amphitheater of unspoken pleas and teary gazes. Murmurs of hesitation lingered like the echos of a forgotten nocturne, punctuated by the reveries steeped in chocolate.

"December 15, 2023‚Äîthe day the veil of Wonka's enchantment first parted," I uttered. Yet, as the elixir wove its sorcery through my veins, an idiosyncratic delusion seized me. The fantastical domain of Wonka began to intermingle with the tangible‚Äîa fusion of chocolate-drenched hallucinations seeping into my discourse.

The Chocolate Cartel hatched schemes in my whimsical cogitations, 500 chocoholic monks chanted in sweet consonance, and giraffes with candy-striped necks roved surreal landscapes. I was served Hoverchocs by the late Baron Vonschmeigelhammer, elevating me into the ethereal, and I soared through clouds of cocoa dust, my utterances metamorphosing into a harmonious blend of sweet delusion and poignant reminiscence.

My family, erstwhile patient auditors to my sugary hallucinations, now implored with desperate timbre, "Father, these illusions bear no substance. Break free from this cacao-induced reverie! The chocolate-swathed giraffes and monks are figments. Recall us, not the mirages that dissolve like toffee in the sun." The pleas encircled me like a somber dark chocolate rivulet, as I grappled with the demarcation between the cocoa-coated dreams and the reality they entreated me to reclaim.

In the concluding moments, the room resonated with the fading murmurs of temporal alchemy, and a bittersweet melody permeated the air. An Oompa Loompa materialized, its diminutive form swaying to a capricious melody:

üé∂"Oompa loompa, doompa dee doo,
In Wonka's realm, there are dreams anew.
Beware the candy's enchanting haze,
Where reality dissolves in a daze.

Chocolate rivers and towering giraffes,
Hoverchocs lift on cocoa wafts.
The Chocolate Cartel whispers delight,
In a world where day fades to night.

Your kin implores, love enduring and true,
To pierce the chocolate, the dreams undue.
Will you emerge from this sugarfied trance,
Or waltz forever in confectionary dance?

Oompa loompa, doompa dee dee,
Reality or fantasy, what shall it be?
The answer floats in the candy air,
As you traverse a world beyond compare."üé∂

The Oompa Loompa's serenade reverberated through the dwindling corridors of my awareness, the dulcet notes intermingling with the elixir's enchantment. The destiny of my reawakening lingered, accompanied by the whimsical melody that swirled like a mist of caramelized reverie, leaving the resolution of my chocolaty dreamscape draped in a saccharine shroud.

title: The Boy and the Heron
reviewText:
ok i think i‚Äôm starting to understand this movie‚Ä¶ maybe. i‚Äôm also beginning to realize that watching ghibli movies as a kid, i never looked for an allegorical meaning in these films. now that i watch this new movie as a 22 year old and struggle to comprehend the plot, i have to look for a metaphor to connect the dots.

some of the puzzle pieces (wip):
- a boy who has to grow up really fast and holds a lot of grief
- a fantastical world where his mother is alive and has control over the thing that killed her (ÁÅ´)
- this world is held up by simple building blocks
- mahito decides to let this world be destroyed and returns to his life
- in the delivery room, his aunt rejects him, saying she hates him
- mahito comes off as extremely stoic for almost all of the film. ghibli leads are often very emotive, but mahito‚Äôs shell cracks only a few times (my favorite of which is when we sees the warawara taking flight).

title: Maestro
reviewText:
the puzzle pieces fell into place for me when spielberg‚Äôs name came up as a producer‚Ä¶ this movie reminds me a lot of The Fabelmans. similar stylization of color, camera movements. also i like how there‚Äôs no 19XX text for the time skips; you just kind of have to acclimate yourself with context clues. and the makeup for bradley cooper is quite impressive.

and the aspect ratio works well. there‚Äôs one (verbal) fight scene that i feel like would normally be shot close to the actors‚Äô faces and cut quickly, but in Maestro the camera was still and the actors‚Äô entire bodies were shown in the frame. the fight was conveyed through their posture and their distance from each other, rather than how angry they looked or how much spit was flying out of their mouths.

i only saw the trailer played once in theaters and it really compelled me to give it a try, even though it‚Äôs not a genre that i would normally have the patience to watch. i liked it! (although it‚Äôs mega mega oscar bait and you can tell cooper is basically begging for it)
